content.webTitle: Morning Mail: 1m-strong Paris unity rally, Lindt siege victim shot by police, Sri Lanka to investigate coup attempt

fields.headline: Morning Mail: 1m-strong Paris unity rally, Lindt siege victim shot by police, Sri Lanka to investigate coup attempt
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox every weekday morning. Paris unity rally An estimated 2 million people have lined the streets of Paris in an “unprecedented” show of unity, with officials saying it was the first time since the Allies liberated Paris from the Nazis in World War II that so many people had taken to the streets. See our coverage of the rally as it happened live, including voices of people from the march: “it’s some kind of closure”. Paris welcomed world leaders to the unity rally against terror attacks, but the presence at the rally of leaders with poor free press records has been condemned. One of the German newspapers that reprinted Muhammad cartoons has been firebombed, and the Paris supermarket attacker claimed allegiance to Islamic State in a video before his attack. In an address “to all the racists, Islamophobes and antisemites”, the brother of Ahmed Merabet, the first police officer at the scene of the Charlie Hebdo attack says his brother was murdered by terrorists, “false Muslims”. Liberal backbencher Cory Bernardi says Australia must revisit the issue of changing the Racial Discrimination Act to protect freedom of speech in the wake of the attacks in France, Rupert Murdoch has been widely criticised for saying all Muslims must be held responsible for the Charlie Hebdo terror attacks, while JK Rowling hit back, saying “I was born Christian. If that makes Rupert Murdoch my responsibility, I’ll auto-excommunicate.” Follow our full Charlie Hedbo coverage here. Australian news and politics Martin Place siege victim Katrina Dawson was struck by a police bullet in the final shootout with gunman Man Haron Monis at the Lindt Cafe, the police investigation has reportedly revealed. Campbell Newman has had an early bounce in the polls as Queensland enters its second week of campaigning ahead of the 31 January state election. Refugees have been released from Australian detention in the past six months after their security assessments were reversed, but there are now grave concerns for the mental health of two who were told they would be released, but have been kept in detention. Around the world Sri Lanka’s new government will investigate an alleged attempt by former president Mahinda Rajapaksa to stage a coup, with claims he attempted to deploy army and police to stop the counting of votes. Tony Abbott called Sri Lanka’s president-elect Maithripala Sirisena to emphasise Australia and Sri Lanka’s “continuing cooperation” on people smuggling and boats. Saudi Arabia is remaining silent in the face of global outrage at the public flogging of jailed blogger Raif Badawi, who is being punished for running a liberal website devoted to freedom of speech. Two suspected child suicide bombers attack Nigerian market, killing three and wounding 26. One last thing The mystery of a ‘severed finger’ found on a Darwin beach has finally been solved. (It’s not a finger) Have an excellent day – and if you spot something I’ve missed, let me know on Twitter @earleyedition.
